page.title: 14A SOUTH HYLTON FARM
page.content: This farm shows clear signs of an industrial history related to the River Wear. In the centre of the present day complex is a building with a chimney set at a different orientation to the other structures which relates directly to an old railway incline down to the river. It is an engine winding house and in front of it is a sequence of cells for loading waggons, or for storage, below from the railway above. The incline proceeds firstly as a cutting, then under a masonry stone arch down to the Wearside quayside level. Alongside the railway is an old quarry site, grown over with trees, and other structures including a chimney. There is evidence of a tunnel. The farm buildings include a square gin house, threshing barn, stables and a blacksmith's.
